001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * Various numeric functions that are important to performance but need alternate implementations on GWT to obtain it.
005 * Super-sourced on GWT, but most things here are direct calls to JDK methods when on desktop or Android.
006 * Some of this code makes use of "creative" bit manipulation of floats and doubles, which can sometimes allow uncommon
007 * input-to-output patterns (as in {@link #bounce(float)}), or even can yield a performance boost (compare
008 * {@link #zigzag(float)} to using modulus to accomplish the same results). The bit manipulation has good performance on
009 * GWT thanks to JS typed arrays, which are well-supported now across all recent browsers and have fallbacks in GWT in
010 * the unlikely event of a browser not supporting them.
011 */
012public final class NumberTools {
013    /**
014     * Identical to {@link Double#doubleToLongBits(double)} on desktop; optimized on GWT. When compiling to JS via GWT,
015     * there is no way to distinguish NaN values with different bits but that are still NaN, so this doesn't try to
016     * somehow permit that. Uses JS typed arrays on GWT, which are well-supported now across all recent browsers and
017     * have fallbacks in GWT in the unlikely event of a browser not supporting them. JS typed arrays support double, but
018     * not long, so this needs to compose a long from two ints, which means the double-to/from-long conversions aren't
019     * as fast as float-to/from-int conversions.
020     * @param value a {@code double} floating-point number.
021     * @return the bits that represent the floating-point number.
022     */
023    public static long doubleToLongBits(final double value)
024    {
025        return Double.doubleToLongBits(value);
026    }
027    /**
028     * Identical to {@link Double#doubleToLongBits(double)} on desktop (note, not
029     * {@link Double#doubleToRawLongBits(double)}); optimized on GWT. When compiling to JS via GWT, there is no way to
030     * distinguish NaN values with different bits but that are still NaN, so this doesn't try to somehow permit that.
031     * Uses JS typed arrays on GWT, which are well-supported now across all recent browsers and have fallbacks in GWT in
032     * the unlikely event of a browser not supporting them. JS typed arrays support double, but not long, so this needs
033     * to compose a long from two ints, which means the double-to/from-long conversions aren't as fast as
034     * float-to/from-int conversions.
035     * @param value a {@code double} floating-point number.
036     * @return the bits that represent the floating-point number.
037     */
038    public static long doubleToRawLongBits(final double value)
039    {
040        return Double.doubleToLongBits(value);
041    }
042
043    /**
044     * Identical to {@link Double#longBitsToDouble(long)} on desktop; optimized on GWT. Uses JS typed arrays on GWT,
045     * which are well-supported now across all recent browsers and have fallbacks in GWT in the unlikely event of a
046     * browser not supporting them. JS typed arrays support double, but not long, so this needs to compose a long from
047     * two ints, which means the double-to/from-long conversions aren't as fast as float-to/from-int conversions.
048     * @param bits a long.
049     * @return the {@code double} floating-point value with the same bit pattern.
050     */
051    public static double longBitsToDouble(final long bits)
052    {
053        return Double.longBitsToDouble(bits);
054    }
055    /**
056     * Converts {@code value} to a long and gets the lower 32 bits of that long, as an int.
057     * @param value a {@code double} precision floating-point number.
058     * @return the lower half of the bits that represent the floating-point number, as an int.
059     */
060    public static int doubleToLowIntBits(final double value)
061    {
062        return (int)(Double.doubleToLongBits(value) & 0xffffffffL);
063    }
064
065    /**
066     * Converts {@code value} to a long and gets the upper 32 bits of that long, as an int.
067     * @param value a {@code double} precision floating-point number.
068     * @return the upper half of the bits that represent the floating-point number, as an int.
069     */
070    public static int doubleToHighIntBits(final double value)
071    {
072        return (int)(Double.doubleToLongBits(value) >>> 32);
073    }
074
075    /**
076     * Converts {@code value} to a long and gets the XOR of its upper and lower 32-bit sections. Useful for numerical
077     * code where a 64-bit double needs to be reduced to a 32-bit value with some hope of keeping different doubles
078     * giving different ints.
079     * @param value a {@code double} precision floating-point number.
080     * @return the XOR of the lower and upper halves of the bits that represent the floating-point number.
081     */
082    public static int doubleToMixedIntBits(final double value)
083    {
084        final long l = Double.doubleToLongBits(value);
085        return (int)(l & 0xFFFFFFFFL) ^ (int)(l >>> 32);
086    }
087
088    /**
089     * Makes a modified version of value that uses the specified bits (up to 12) for its exponent and sign.
090     * Meant for some specific cases, like adjusting the exponent on an unknown double to the 1.0 to 2.0 range (which
091     * would pass 0x3ff for exponentBits). If you have a double from 1.0 to 2.0, you can subtract 1.0 from it to get the
092     * often-desirable 0.0-1.0 range. Other common cases are 0x400, which adjusts to between 2.0 and 4.0 (subtracting
093     * 3.0 from this gives the -1.0 to 1.0 range, useful for noise), and 0xBFF, which adjusts to between -2.0 and -1.0.
094     * For the last case, you might think that -0x3ff would work, but sadly it doesn't. You can use
095     * {@code exponentBits |= 0x800} to set the sign bit to negative, or {@code exponentBits &= 0x7ff} for positive.
096     * @param value a double that will have its sign and exponent set to the specified bits
097     * @param exponentBits the bits to use for the sign and exponent section of the returned modification of value
098     * @return the double produced by keeping the significand of value but changing its exponent and sign as given
099     */
100    public static double setExponent(final double value, final int exponentBits)
101    {
102        return Double.longBitsToDouble((Double.doubleToLongBits(value) & 0xfffffffffffffL) | ((long) exponentBits << 52));
103    }
104
105    /**
106     * Gets an 8-bit section of the given double {@code value}, using {@code whichByte} to select whether this should
107     * return byte 0 (least significant), 1, 2, and so on up to 7 (most significant).
108     * @param value a float
109     * @param whichByte an int that will be used to select the byte to take from value (any int is allowed, only the bottom 3 bits are used to select)
110     * @return the selected byte from the given float
111     */
112    public static byte getSelectedByte(final double value, final int whichByte)
113    {
114        return (byte)(Double.doubleToLongBits(value) >>> ((whichByte & 7) << 3));
115    }
116
117    /**
118     * Like {@link #getSelectedByte(double, int)}, this sets the byte at a selected position in the int representation of
119     * a double, then returns the double produced by the bit change. Uses {@code whichByte} to select whether this should
120     * set byte 0 (least significant), 1, 2, and so on up to 7 (most significant). {@code newValue} is a byte.
121     * @param value a double
122     * @param whichByte an int that will be used to select the byte to take from value (any int is allowed, only the bottom 3 bits are used to select)
123     * @param newValue a byte that will be placed into the returned double's bits at the selected position
124     * @return a double that results from changing the bits at the selected position to match newValue
125     */
126    public static double setSelectedByte(final double value, final int whichByte, final byte newValue)
127    {
128        return Double.longBitsToDouble((Double.doubleToLongBits(value) & ~(255 << ((whichByte & 7) << 3)))
129                | ((newValue & 255) << ((whichByte & 7) << 3)));
130    }
131
132    /**
133     * Very limited-use; takes any double and produces a double in the -1.0 to 1.0 range, with similar inputs producing
134     * close to a consistent rate of up and down through the range. This is meant for noise, where it may be useful to
135     * limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent sudden "jumps" in noise value.
136     * @param value any double
137     * @return a double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)
138     */
139    public static double bounce(final double value)
140    {
141        final long s = Double.doubleToLongBits(value);
142        return Double.longBitsToDouble(((s ^ -((s & 0x8000000000000L)>>51)) & 0xfffffffffffffL)
143                | 0x4010000000000000L) - 5.0;
144    }
145
146    /**
147     * Very limited-use; takes any double and produces a double in the -1.0 to 1.0 range, with similar inputs producing
148     * close to a consistent rate of up and down through the range. This is meant for noise, where it may be useful to
149     * limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent sudden "jumps" in noise value.
150     * @param value any double
151     * @return a double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)
152     */
153    public static float bounce(final float value)
154    {
155        final int s = Float.floatToIntBits(value);
156        return Float.intBitsToFloat(((s ^ -((s & 0x00400000)>>22)) & 0x007fffff)
157                | 0x40800000) - 5f;
158    }
159    /**
160     * Very limited-use; takes the significand bits of a double, represented as a long of which this uses 52 bits, and
161     * produces a double in the -1.0 to 1.0 range, with similar inputs producing close to a consistent rate of up and
162     * down through the range. This is meant for noise, where it may be useful to limit the amount of change between
163     * nearby points' noise values and prevent sudden "jumps" in noise value.
164     * @param value any long; only the lower 52 bits will be used
165     * @return a double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)
166     */
167    public static double bounce(final long value)
168    {
169        return Double.longBitsToDouble(((value ^ -((value & 0x8000000000000L)>>51)) & 0xfffffffffffffL)
170                | 0x4010000000000000L) - 5.0;
171    }
172    /**
173     * Very limited-use; takes the significand bits of a double, represented as a pair of ints {@code valueLow} and
174     * {@code valueHigh}, using all bits in valueLow and the least-significant 20 bits of valueHigh, and
175     * produces a double in the -1.0 to 1.0 range, with similar inputs producing close to a consistent rate of up and
176     * down through the range. This is meant for noise, where it may be useful to limit the amount of change between
177     * nearby points' noise values and prevent sudden "jumps" in noise value.
178     * @param valueLow any int; all bits will be used as the less-significant bits of the significand
179     * @param valueHigh any int; only the bottom 20 bits will be used as the more-significant bits of the significand
180     * @return a double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)
181     */
182
183    public static double bounce(final int valueLow, final int valueHigh)
184    {
185        final long s = (((long) valueHigh) << 32 | valueLow);
186        return Double.longBitsToDouble(((s ^ -((s & 0x8000000000000L)>>51)) & 0xfffffffffffffL)
187                | 0x4010000000000000L) - 5.0;
188    }
189
190    /**
191     * Limited-use; takes any double and produces a double in the -1.0 to 1.0 range, with similar inputs producing
192     * close to a consistent rate of up and down through the range. This is meant for noise, where it may be useful to
193     * limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent sudden "jumps" in noise value. It is
194     * very similar to {@link #bounce(double)}, but unlike bounce() this will maintain a continuous rate regardless of
195     * the magnitude of its input. An input of any even number should produce something very close to -1.0, any odd
196     * number should produce something very close to 1.0, and any number halfway between two incremental integers (like
197     * 8.5 or -10.5) should produce 0.0 or a very small fraction. This method is closely related to
198     * {@link #sway(double)}, which will smoothly curve its output to produce more values that are close to -1 or 1.
199     * @param value any double
200     * @return a double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (inclusive)
201     */
202    public static double zigzag(double value)
203    {
204        long floor = (value >= 0.0 ? (long) value : (long) value - 1L);
205        value -= floor;
206        floor = (-(floor & 1L) | 1L);
207        return value * (floor << 1) - floor;
208    }
209
210    /**
211     * Limited-use; takes any float and produces a float in the -1f to 1f range, with similar inputs producing
212     * close to a consistent rate of up and down through the range. This is meant for noise, where it may be useful to
213     * limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent sudden "jumps" in noise value. It is
214     * very similar to {@link #bounce(float)}, but unlike bounce() this will maintain a continuous rate regardless of
215     * the magnitude of its input. An input of any even number should produce something very close to -1f, any odd
216     * number should produce something very close to 1f, and any number halfway between two incremental integers (like
217     * 8.5f or -10.5f) should produce 0f or a very small fraction. This method is closely related to
218     * {@link #sway(float)}, which will smoothly curve its output to produce more values that are close to -1 or 1.
219     * @param value any float
220     * @return a float from -1f (inclusive) to 1f (inclusive)
221     */
222    public static float zigzag(float value)
223    {
224        int floor = (value >= 0f ? (int) value : (int) value - 1);
225        value -= floor;
226        floor = (-(floor & 1) | 1);
227        return value * (floor << 1) - floor;
228    }
229
230    /**
231     * Limited-use; takes any double and produces a double in the -1 to 1 range, with a graph of input to output that
232     * looks much like a sine wave, curving to have a flat slope when given an integer input and a steep slope when the
233     * input is halfway between two integers, smoothly curving at any points between those extremes. This is meant for
234     * noise, where it may be useful to limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent both
235     * sudden "jumps" in noise value and "cracks" where a line takes a sudden jagged movement at an angle. It is very
236     * similar to {@link #bounce(double)} and {@link #zigzag(double)}, but unlike bounce() this will maintain its
237     * frequency of returning max or min values, regardless of the magnitude of its input (as long as there is enough
238     * floating-point precision to represent changes smaller than 1.0), and unlike zigzag() this will smooth its path.
239     * An input of any even number should produce something very close to -1.0, any odd number should produce something
240     * very close to 1.0, and any number halfway between two incremental integers (like 8.5 or -10.5) should produce 0.0
241     * or a very small fraction. In the (unlikely) event that this is given a double that is too large to represent
242     * many or any non-integer values, this will simply return -1.0 or 1.0.
243     * @param value any double other than NaN or infinite values; extremely large values can't work properly
244     * @return a double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (inclusive)
245     */
246    public static double sway(double value)
247    {
248        long floor = (value >= 0.0 ? (long) value : (long) value - 1L);
249        value -= floor;
250        floor = (-(floor & 1L) | 1L);
251        return value * value * value * (value * (value * 6.0 - 15.0) + 10.0) * (floor << 1) - floor;
252    }
253
254    /**
255     * Limited-use; takes any float and produces a float in the -1f to 1f range, with a graph of input to output that
256     * looks much like a sine wave, curving to have a flat slope when given an integer input and a steep slope when the
257     * input is halfway between two integers, smoothly curving at any points between those extremes. This is meant for
258     * noise, where it may be useful to limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent both
259     * sudden "jumps" in noise value and "cracks" where a line takes a sudden jagged movement at an angle. It is very
260     * similar to {@link #bounce(float)} and {@link #zigzag(float)}, but unlike bounce() this will maintain its
261     * frequency of returning max or min values, regardless of the magnitude of its input (as long as there is enough
262     * floating-point precision to represent changes smaller than 1f), and unlike zigzag() this will smooth its path.
263     * An input of any even number should produce something very close to -1f, any odd number should produce something
264     * very close to 1f, and any number halfway between two incremental integers (like 8.5f or -10.5f) should produce 0f
265     * or a very small fraction. In the (unlikely) event that this is given a float that is too large to represent
266     * many or any non-integer values, this will simply return -1f or 1f.
267     * @param value any float other than NaN or infinite values; extremely large values can't work properly
268     * @return a float from -1f (inclusive) to 1f (inclusive)
269     */
270    public static float sway(float value)
271    {
272        int floor = (value >= 0f ? (int) value : (int) value - 1);
273        value -= floor;
274        floor = (-(floor & 1) | 1);
275        return value * value * value * (value * (value * 6f - 15f) + 10f) * (floor << 1) - floor;
276    }
277
278    /**
279     * Limited-use; takes any float and produces a float in the 0f to 1f range, with a graph of input to output that
280     * looks much like a sine wave, curving to have a flat slope when given an integer input and a steep slope when the
281     * input is halfway between two integers, smoothly curving at any points between those extremes. This is meant for
282     * noise, where it may be useful to limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent both
283     * sudden "jumps" in noise value and "cracks" where a line takes a sudden jagged movement at an angle. It is very
284     * similar to {@link #bounce(float)} and {@link #zigzag(float)}, but unlike bounce() this will not change its
285     * frequency of returning max or min values, regardless of the magnitude of its input (as long as there is enough
286     * floating-point precision to represent changes smaller than 1f), and unlike zigzag() this will smooth its path.
287     * An input of any even number should produce something very close to 0f, any odd number should produce something
288     * very close to 1f, and any number halfway between two incremental integers (like 8.5f or -10.5f) should produce
289     * 0.5f. In the (unlikely) event that this is given a float that is too large to represent many or any non-integer
290     * values, this will simply return 0f or 1f. This version is called "Tight" because its range is tighter than
291     * {@link #sway(float)}.
292     * @param value any float other than NaN or infinite values; extremely large values can't work properly
293     * @return a float from 0f (inclusive) to 1f (inclusive)
294     */
295    public static float swayTight(float value)
296    {
297        int floor = (value >= 0f ? (int) value : (int) value - 1);
298        value -= floor;
299        floor &= 1;
300        return value * value * value * (value * (value * 6f - 15f) + 10f) * (-floor | 1) + floor;
301    }
302
303    /**
304     * Limited-use; takes any double and produces a double in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, with a graph of input to output that
305     * looks much like a sine wave, curving to have a flat slope when given an integer input and a steep slope when the
306     * input is halfway between two integers, smoothly curving at any points between those extremes. This is meant for
307     * noise, where it may be useful to limit the amount of change between nearby points' noise values and prevent both
308     * sudden "jumps" in noise value and "cracks" where a line takes a sudden jagged movement at an angle. It is very
309     * similar to {@link #bounce(double)} and {@link #zigzag(double)}, but unlike bounce() this will not change its
310     * frequency of returning max or min values, regardless of the magnitude of its input (as long as there is enough
311     * floating-point precision to represent changes smaller than 1.0), and unlike zigzag() this will smooth its path.
312     * An input of any even number should produce something very close to 0.0, any odd number should produce something
313     * very close to 1.0, and any number halfway between two incremental integers (like 8.5 or -10.5) should produce
314     * 0.5f. In the (unlikely) event that this is given a double that is too large to represent many or any non-integer
315     * values, this will simply return 0.0 or 1.0. This version is called "Tight" because its range is tighter than
316     * {@link #sway(double)}.
317     * @param value any double other than NaN or infinite values; extremely large values can't work properly
318     * @return a double from 0.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (inclusive)
319     */
320    public static double swayTight(double value)
321    {
322        long floor = (value >= 0.0 ? (long) value : (long) value - 1L);
323        value -= floor;
324        floor &= 1L;
325        return value * value * value * (value * (value * 6.0 - 15.0) + 10.0) * (-floor | 1L) + floor;
326    }
327
328    /**
329     * A mix of the smooth transitions of {@link #sway(double)} with (seeded) random peaks and valleys between -1.0 and
330     * 1.0 (both exclusive). The pattern this will produces will be completely different if the seed changes, and it is
331     * suitable for 1D noise. Uses a simple method of cubic interpolation between random values, where a random value is
332     * used without modification when given an integer for {@code value}. Note that this uses a different type of
333     * interpolation than {@link #sway(double)}, which uses quintic (this causes swayRandomized() to produce more
334     * outputs in the mid-range and less at extremes; it is also slightly faster and simpler).
335     * <br>
336     * Performance note: HotSpot seems to be much more able to optimize swayRandomized(long, float) than
337     * swayRandomized(long, double), with the float version almost twice as fast after JIT warms up. On GWT, the
338     * reverse should be expected because floats must be emulated there.
339     * @param seed a long seed that will determine the pattern of peaks and valleys this will generate as value changes; this should not change between calls
340     * @param value a double that typically changes slowly, by less than 1.0, with direction changes at integer inputs
341     * @return a pseudo-random double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both exclusive), smoothly changing with value
342     */
343    public static double swayRandomized(long seed, double value)
344    {
345        final long floor = value >= 0.0 ? (long) value : (long) value - 1L; // the closest long that is less than value
346        // gets a random start and endpoint. there's a sequence of start and end values for each seed, and changing the
347        // seed changes the start and end values unpredictably (so use the same seed for one curving line).
348        final double start = (((seed += floor * 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) * 0x0.fffffffffffffbp-63,
349                end = (((seed += 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) * 0x0.fffffffffffffbp-63;
350        // gets the fractional part of value
351        value -= floor;
352        // cubic interpolation to smooth the curve
353        value *= value * (3.0 - 2.0 * value);
354        // interpolate between start and end based on how far we are between the start and end points of this section
355        return (1.0 - value) * start + value * end;
356    }
357
358    /**
359     * A mix of the smooth transitions of {@link #sway(float)} with (seeded) random peaks and valleys between -1f and
360     * 1f (both exclusive). The pattern this will produces will be completely different if the seed changes, and it is
361     * suitable for 1D noise. Uses a simple method of cubic interpolation between random values, where a random value is
362     * used without modification when given an integer for {@code value}. Note that this uses a different type of
363     * interpolation than {@link #sway(float)}, which uses quintic (this causes swayRandomized() to produce more
364     * outputs in the mid-range and less at extremes; it is also slightly faster and simpler).
365     * <br>
366     * Performance note: HotSpot seems to be much more able to optimize swayRandomized(long, float) than
367     * swayRandomized(long, double), with the float version almost twice as fast after JIT warms up. On GWT, the
368     * reverse should be expected because floats must be emulated there.
369     * @param seed a long seed that will determine the pattern of peaks and valleys this will generate as value changes; this should not change between calls
370     * @param value a float that typically changes slowly, by less than 2.0, with direction changes at integer inputs
371     * @return a pseudo-random float between -1f and 1f (both exclusive), smoothly changing with value
372     */
373    public static float swayRandomized(long seed, float value)
374    {
375        final long floor = value >= 0f ? (long) value : (long) value - 1L;
376        final float start = (((seed += floor * 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) * 0x0.ffffffp-63f,
377                end = (((seed += 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) * 0x0.ffffffp-63f;
378        value -= floor;
379        value *= value * (3f - 2f * value);
380        return (1f - value) * start + value * end;
381    }
382    
383    /**
384     * A variant on {@link #swayRandomized(long, float)} that takes an int seed instead of a float, and is optimized for
385     * usage on GWT. Like the version with a long seed, this uses cubic interpolation between random peak or valley
386     * points; only the method of generating those random peaks and valleys has changed.
387     * @param seed an int seed that will determine the pattern of peaks and valleys this will generate as value changes; this should not change between calls
388     * @param value a float that typically changes slowly, by less than 2.0, with direction changes at integer inputs
389     * @return a pseudo-random float between -1f and 1f (both exclusive), smoothly changing with value
390     */
391    public static float swayRandomized(final int seed, float value)
392    {
393        final int floor = value >= 0f ? (int) value : (int) value - 1;
394        int z = seed + floor;
395        final float start = (((z = (z ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x102473) ^ (z << 11 | z >>> 21) ^ (z << 19 | z >>> 13)) * ((z ^ z >>> 15) | 0xFFE00001) ^ z) * 0x0.ffffffp-31f,
396                end = (((z = (seed + floor + 1 ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x102473) ^ (z << 11 | z >>> 21) ^ (z << 19 | z >>> 13)) * ((z ^ z >>> 15) | 0xFFE00001) ^ z) * 0x0.ffffffp-31f;
397        value -= floor;
398        value *= value * (3 - 2 * value);
399        return (1 - value) * start + value * end;
400    }
401    /**
402     * A 1D "noise" method that produces smooth transitions like {@link #sway(float)}, but also wrapping around at pi *
403     * 2 so this can be used to get smoothly-changing random angles. Has (seeded) random peaks and valleys where it
404     * slows its range of change, but can return any value from 0 to 6.283185307179586f, or pi * 2. The pattern this
405     * will produces will be completely different if the seed changes, and the value is expected to be something other
406     * than an angle, like time. Uses a simple method of cubic interpolation between random values, where a random value
407     * is used without modification when given an integer for {@code value}. Note that this uses a different type of
408     * interpolation than {@link #sway(float)}, which uses quintic (this causes swayAngleRandomized() to be slightly
409     * faster and simpler).
410     * @param seed a long seed that will determine the pattern of peaks and valleys this will generate as value changes; this should not change between calls
411     * @param value a float that typically changes slowly, by less than 1.0, with possible direction changes at integer inputs
412     * @return a pseudo-random float between 0f and 283185307179586f (both inclusive), smoothly changing with value and wrapping
413     */
414    public static float swayAngleRandomized(long seed, float value)
415    {
416        final long floor = value >= 0f ? (long) value : (long) value - 1L;
417        float start = (((seed += floor * 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L) >>> 1) * 0x0.ffffffp-62f,
418                end = (((seed += 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L) >>> 1) * 0x0.ffffffp-62f;
419        value -= floor;
420        value *= value * (3f - 2f * value);
421        end = end - start + 1.5f;
422        end -= (long)end + 0.5f;
423        start += end * value + 1;
424        return (start - (long)start) * 6.283185307179586f;
425    }
426    
427    /**
428     * Identical to {@link Float#floatToIntBits(float)} on desktop; optimized on GWT. Uses JS typed arrays on GWT, which
429     * are well-supported now across all recent browsers and have fallbacks in GWT in the unlikely event of a browser
430     * not supporting them.
431     * @param value a floating-point number.
432     * @return the bits that represent the floating-point number.
433     */
434    public static int floatToIntBits(final float value)
435    {
436        return Float.floatToIntBits(value);
437    }
438    /**
439     * Identical to {@link Float#floatToIntBits(float)} on desktop (note, not {@link Float#floatToRawIntBits(float)});
440     * optimized on GWT. When compiling to JS via GWT, there is no way to distinguish NaN values with different bits but
441     * that are still NaN, so this doesn't try to somehow permit that. Uses JS typed arrays on GWT, which are
442     * well-supported now across all recent browsers and have fallbacks in GWT in the unlikely event of a browser not
443     * supporting them.
444     * @param value a floating-point number.
445     * @return the bits that represent the floating-point number.
446     */
447    public static int floatToRawIntBits(final float value)
448    {
449        return Float.floatToIntBits(value);
450    }
451
452
453    /**
454     * Gets the bit representation of the given float {@code value}, but with reversed byte order. On desktop, this is
455     * equivalent to calling {@code Integer.reverseBytes(Float.floatToIntBits(value))}, but it is implemented using
456     * typed arrays on GWT.
457     * @param value a floating-point number
458     * @return the bits that represent the floating-point number, with their byte order reversed from normal.
459     */
460    public static int floatToReversedIntBits(final float value) {
461        return Integer.reverseBytes(Float.floatToIntBits(value));
462    }
463
464    /**
465     * Reverses the byte order of {@code bits} and converts that to a float. On desktop, this is
466     * equivalent to calling {@code Float.intBitsToFloat(Integer.reverseBytes(bits))}, but it is implemented using
467     * typed arrays on GWT.
468     * @param bits an integer
469     * @return the {@code float} floating-point value with the given bits using their byte order reversed from normal.
470     */
471    public static float reversedIntBitsToFloat(final int bits) {
472        return Float.intBitsToFloat(Integer.reverseBytes(bits));
473    }
474
475    /**
476     * Identical to {@link Float#intBitsToFloat(int)} on desktop; optimized on GWT. Uses JS typed arrays on GWT, which
477     * are well-supported now across all recent browsers and have fallbacks in GWT in the unlikely event of a browser
478     * not supporting them.
479     * @param bits an integer.
480     * @return the {@code float} floating-point value with the same bit pattern.
481     */
482    public static float intBitsToFloat(final int bits)
483    {
484        return Float.intBitsToFloat(bits);
485    }
486
487    /**
488     * Gets an 8-bit section of the given float {@code value}, using {@code whichByte} to select whether this should
489     * return byte 0 (least significant), 1, 2, or 3 (most significant).
490     * @param value a float
491     * @param whichByte an int that will be used to select the byte to take from value (any int is allowed, only the bottom 2 bits are used to select)
492     * @return the selected byte from the given float
493     */
494    public static byte getSelectedByte(final float value, final int whichByte)
495    {
496        return (byte)(Float.floatToIntBits(value) >>> ((whichByte & 3) << 3));
497    }
498
499    /**
500     * Like {@link #getSelectedByte(float, int)}, this sets the byte at a selected position in the int representation of
501     * a float, then returns the float produced by the bit change. Uses {@code whichByte} to select whether this should
502     * set byte 0 (least significant), 1, 2, or 3 (most significant). {@code newValue} is a byte.
503     * @param value a float
504     * @param whichByte an int that will be used to select the byte to take from value (any int is allowed, only the bottom 2 bits are used to select)
505     * @param newValue a byte that will be placed into the returned float's bits at the selected position
506     * @return a float that results from changing the bits at the selected position to match newValue
507     */
508    public static float setSelectedByte(final float value, final int whichByte, final byte newValue)
509    {
510        return Float.intBitsToFloat((Float.floatToIntBits(value) & ~(255 << ((whichByte & 3) << 3)))
511                | ((newValue & 255) << ((whichByte & 3) << 3)));
512    }
513
514    /**
515     * Generates a pseudo-random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive) using the given long seed, passing
516     * it once through the (decent-quality and very fast) {@link ThrustAltRNG} algorithm.
517     * <br>
518     * Consider calling this with {@code NumberTools.randomDouble(++seed)} for an optimal period of 2 to the 64 when
519     * repeatedly called, but {@code NumberTools.randomDouble(seed += ODD_LONG)} will also work just fine if ODD_LONG is
520     * any odd-number long, positive or negative.
521     * @param seed any long to be used as a seed
522     * @return a pseudo-random double from 0.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)
523     */
524    public static double randomDouble(long seed)
525    {
526        return (((seed = ((seed *= 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) ^ (seed >>> 23)) & 0x1FFFFFFFFFFFFFL) * 0x1p-53;
527    }
528
529    /**
530     * Generates a pseudo-random double between -1.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive) using the given long seed, passing
531     * it once through the (decent-quality and very fast) {@link ThrustAltRNG} algorithm.
532     * <br>
533     * Consider calling this with {@code NumberTools.randomSignedDouble(++seed)} for an optimal period of 2 to the 64
534     * when repeatedly called, but {@code NumberTools.randomSignedDouble(seed += ODD_LONG)} will also work just fine if
535     * ODD_LONG is any odd-number long, positive or negative.
536     * @param seed any long to be used as a seed
537     * @return a pseudo-random double from 0.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)
538     */
539    public static double randomSignedDouble(long seed)
540    {
541        return (((seed = ((seed *= 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) ^ (seed >>> 23)) >> 10) * 0x1p-53;
542    }
543    /**
544     * Generates a pseudo-random float between 0f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive) using the given long seed, passing it
545     * once through the (decent-quality and very fast) {@link ThrustAltRNG} algorithm.
546     * <br>
547     * Consider calling this with {@code NumberTools.randomFloat(++seed)} for an optimal period of 2 to the 64 when
548     * repeatedly called, but {@code NumberTools.randomFloat(seed += ODD_LONG)} will also work just fine if ODD_LONG is
549     * any odd-number long, positive or negative.
550     * @param seed any long to be used as a seed
551     * @return a pseudo-random float from -1.0f (exclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive)
552     */
553    public static float randomFloat(long seed)
554    {
555        return (((seed = ((seed *= 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) ^ (seed >>> 23)) & 0xFFFFFF) * 0x1p-24f;
556    }
557    /**
558     * Generates a pseudo-random float between -1f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive) using the given long seed, passing
559     * it once through the (decent-quality and very fast) {@link ThrustAltRNG} algorithm. This can be useful as a
560     * multiplier that has approximately equal likelihood of changing or leaving the sign of its multiplicand, and won't
561     * make the result larger (more significant) but will usually make it closer to 0.
562     * <br>
563     * Consider calling this with {@code NumberTools.randomDouble(++seed)} for an optimal period of 2 to the 64 when
564     * repeatedly called, but {@code NumberTools.randomDouble(seed += ODD_LONG)} will also work just fine if ODD_LONG is
565     * any odd-number long, positive or negative.
566     * @param seed any long to be used as a seed
567     * @return a pseudo-random float from -1.0f (exclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive)
568     */
569    public static float randomSignedFloat(long seed)
570    {
571        return (((seed = ((seed *= 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) ^ (seed >>> 23)) >> 39) * 0x1p-24f;
572    }
573
574    /**
575     * Generates a pseudo-random double between -1.0 (exclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive) with a distribution that has a
576     * strong central bias (around 0.0). Uses the given long seed, passing it once through the (decent-quality and very
577     * fast) {@link ThrustAltRNG} algorithm. This produces a pseudo-random long, which this simply passes to
578     * {@link #formCurvedFloat(long)}, since it is already well-suited to generating a curved distribution.
579     * <br>
580     * Consider calling this with {@code NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(++seed)} for an optimal period of 2 to the 64
581     * when repeatedly called, but {@code NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(seed += ODD_LONG)} will also work just fine if
582     * ODD_LONG is any odd-number long, positive or negative.
583     * @param seed any int to be used as a seed
584     * @return a pseudo-random double from -1.0 (exclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive), distributed on a curve centered on 0.0
585     */
586    public static float randomFloatCurved(long seed)
587    {
588        return formCurvedFloat(((seed = ((seed *= 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) ^ (seed >>> 25)) * (seed | 0xA529L)) ^ (seed >>> 23)));
589    }
590
591    /**
592     * Given an int as a seed, this uses its least-significant 23 bits to produce a float between 0f (inclusive) and 1f
593     * (exclusive). This does not randomize the seed at all, and the upper 9 bits of the seed are ignored.
594     * @param seed an int; only the bottom 23 bits will be used
595     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive)
596     */
597    public static float formFloat(final int seed)
598    {
599        return Float.intBitsToFloat((seed & 0x7FFFFF) | 0x3f800000) - 1f;
600    }
601    /**
602     * Given an int as a seed, this uses its least-significant 23 bits to produce a float between -1f (inclusive) and 1f
603     * (exclusive). This does not randomize the seed at all, and the upper 9 bits of the seed are ignored.
604     * @param seed an int; only the bottom 23 bits will be used
605     * @return a float between -1f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive)
606     */
607    public static float formSignedFloat(final int seed)
608    {
609        return Float.intBitsToFloat((seed & 0x7FFFFF) | 0x40000000) - 3f;
610    }
611
612    /**
613     * Given a long as a seed, this uses its least-significant 52 bits to produce a double between 0 (inclusive) and 1
614     * (exclusive). This does not randomize the seed at all, and the upper 12 bits of the seed are ignored.
615     * @param seed a long; only the bottom 52 bits will be used
616     * @return a double between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive)
617     */
618    public static double formDouble(final long seed)
619    {
620        return Double.longBitsToDouble((seed & 0xfffffffffffffL) | 0x3ff0000000000000L) - 1f;
621    }
622    /**
623     * Given a long as a seed, this uses its least-significant 52 bits to produce a double between -1 (inclusive) and 1
624     * (exclusive). This does not randomize the seed at all, and the upper 12 bits of the seed are ignored.
625     * @param seed a long; only the bottom 52 bits will be used
626     * @return a double between -1 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive)
627     */
628    public static double formSignedDouble(final long seed)
629    {
630        return Double.longBitsToDouble((seed & 0xfffffffffffffL) | 0x4000000000000000L) - 3f;
631    }
632
633    /**
634     * A different kind of determine-like method that expects to be given a random long and produces a random double
635     * with a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely) approach -1f and 1f.
636     * The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near -1.0
637     * or 1.0. It cannot produce 1.0, -1.0, or any values further from 0 than those bounds.
638     * @param start a long, usually random, such as one produced by any RandomnessSource; all bits will be used
639     * @return a deterministic double between -1.0 (exclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive); very likely to be close to 0.0
640     */
641    public static double formCurvedDouble(long start) {
642        return    longBitsToDouble((start >>> 12) | 0x3fe0000000000000L)
643                + longBitsToDouble(((start *= 0x2545F4914F6CDD1DL) >>> 12) | 0x3fe0000000000000L)
644                - longBitsToDouble(((start *= 0x2545F4914F6CDD1DL) >>> 12) | 0x3fe0000000000000L)
645                - longBitsToDouble(((start *  0x2545F4914F6CDD1DL) >>> 12) | 0x3fe0000000000000L)
646                ;
647    }
648    /**
649     * A different kind of determine-like method that expects to be given a random long and produces a random double
650     * with a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely) approach 0.0 and 1.0.
651     * The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near 0.0 or
652     * 1.0. It cannot produce 0.0, 1.0, or any values further from 0.5 than those bounds.
653     * @param start a long, usually random, such as one produced by any RandomnessSource; all bits will be used
654     * @return a deterministic double between 0.0 (exclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive); very likely to be close to 0.5
655     */
656    public static double formCurvedDoubleTight(long start) {
657        return  0.5
658                + longBitsToDouble((start >>> 12) | 0x3fd0000000000000L)
659                + longBitsToDouble(((start *= 0x2545F4914F6CDD1DL) >>> 12) | 0x3fd0000000000000L)
660                - longBitsToDouble(((start *= 0x2545F4914F6CDD1DL) >>> 12) | 0x3fd0000000000000L)
661                - longBitsToDouble(((start *  0x2545F4914F6CDD1DL) >>> 12) | 0x3fd0000000000000L);
662    }
663
664    /**
665     * A different kind of determine-like method that expects to be given a random long and produces a random float with
666     * a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely) approach -1f and 1f.
667     * The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near -1f or
668     * 1f. It cannot produce 1f, -1f, or any values further from 0 than those bounds.
669     * @param start a long, usually random, such as one produced by any RandomnessSource
670     * @return a deterministic float between -1f (exclusive) and 1f (exclusive), that is very likely to be close to 0f
671     */
672    public static float formCurvedFloat(final long start) {
673        return    intBitsToFloat((int)start >>> 9 | 0x3F000000)
674                + intBitsToFloat((int) (start >>> 41) | 0x3F000000)
675                - intBitsToFloat(((int)(start ^ ~start >>> 20) & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
676                - intBitsToFloat(((int) (~start ^ start >>> 30) & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
677                ;
678    }
679
680    /**
681     * A different kind of determine-like method that expects to be given random ints and produces a random float with
682     * a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely) approach -1f and 1f.
683     * The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near -1f or
684     * 1f. It cannot produce 1f, -1f, or any values further from 0 than those bounds.
685     * @param start1 an int usually random, such as one produced by any RandomnessSource
686     * @param start2 an int usually random, such as one produced by any RandomnessSource
687     * @return a deterministic float between -1f (exclusive) and 1f (exclusive), that is very likely to be close to 0f
688     */
689    public static float formCurvedFloat(final int start1, final int start2) {
690        return    intBitsToFloat(start1 >>> 9 | 0x3F000000)
691                + intBitsToFloat((~start1 & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
692                - intBitsToFloat(start2 >>> 9 | 0x3F000000)
693                - intBitsToFloat((~start2 & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
694                ;
695    }
696    /**
697     * A different kind of determine-like method that expects to be given a random int and produces a random float with
698     * a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely) approach -1f and 1f.
699     * The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near -1f or
700     * 1f. It cannot produce 1f, -1f, or any values further from 0 than those bounds.
701     * @param start an int, usually random, such as one produced by any RandomnessSource
702     * @return a deterministic float between -1f (exclusive) and 1f (exclusive), that is very likely to be close to 0f
703     */
704    public static float formCurvedFloat(final int start) {
705        return    intBitsToFloat(start >>> 9 | 0x3F000000)
706                + intBitsToFloat((start & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
707                - intBitsToFloat(((start << 18 & 0x007FFFFF) ^ ~start >>> 14) | 0x3F000000)
708                - intBitsToFloat(((start << 13 & 0x007FFFFF) ^ ~start >>> 19) | 0x3F000000)
709                ;
710    }
711
712    /**
713     * Returns an int value with at most a single one-bit, in the position of the lowest-order ("rightmost") one-bit in
714     * the specified int value. Returns zero if the specified value has no one-bits in its two's complement binary
715     * representation, that is, if it is equal to zero.
716     * <br>
717     * Identical to {@link Integer#lowestOneBit(int)}, but super-sourced to act correctly on GWT. If you have GWT as a
718     * target and do bit manipulation work, double-check everything! An int can be higher than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}
719     * or lower than {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} on GWT, without actually being a long (internally it's a double). This
720     * is especially relevant for the overload of this method that takes and returns a long;
721     * {@link Long#lowestOneBit(long)} does not provide correct results for certain inputs on GWT, such as
722     * -17592186044416L, which it mysteriously returns 0L on, so you should use {@link #lowestOneBit(long)}.
723     * @param num the value whose lowest one bit is to be computed
724     * @return an int value with a single one-bit, in the position of the lowest-order one-bit in the specified value,
725     *         or zero if the specified value is itself equal to zero.
726     */
727    public static int lowestOneBit(int num)
728    {
729        return num & -num;
730    }
731    /**
732     * Returns an long value with at most a single one-bit, in the position of the lowest-order ("rightmost") one-bit in
733     * the specified long value. Returns zero if the specified value has no one-bits in its two's complement binary
734     * representation, that is, if it is equal to zero.
735     * <br>
736     * Identical to {@link Long#lowestOneBit(long)}, but super-sourced to act correctly on GWT. If you have GWT as a
737     * target and do bit manipulation work, double-check everything! An int can be higher than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}
738     * or lower than {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} on GWT, without actually being a long (internally it's a double). This
739     * is especially relevant for this overload (for longs more so than for ints); {@link Long#lowestOneBit(long)} does
740     * not provide correct results for certain inputs on GWT, such as -17592186044416L, which it mysteriously returns 0L
741     * on, so you should use this method.
742     * @param num the value whose lowest one bit is to be computed
743     * @return a long value with a single one-bit, in the position of the lowest-order one-bit in the specified value,
744     *         or zero if the specified value is itself equal to zero.
745     */
746    public static long lowestOneBit(long num)
747    {
748        return num & -num;
749    }
750
751    /**
752     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
753     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
754     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
755     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
756     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
757     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
758     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
759     * is closely related to {@link #sway(double)}, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
760     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
761     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
762     * potentially higher errors, though.
763     * <br>
764     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin(float)}, so you should
765     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
766     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
767     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
768     * and likewise for doubles.
769     * <br>
770     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
771     * by a measurable amount.
772     * <br>
773     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
774     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
775     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
776     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
777     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
778     */
779
780    public static double sin(double radians)
781    {
782        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
783        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
784        radians -= floor;
785        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
786        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
787    }
788
789    /**
790     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
791     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
792     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
793     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
794     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
795     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
796     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
797     * is closely related to {@link #sway(double)}, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
798     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
799     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
800     * potentially higher errors, though.
801     * <br>
802     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos(float)}, so you should
803     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
804     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
805     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
806     * and likewise for doubles.
807     * <br>
808     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
809     * by a measurable amount.
810     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
811     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
812     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
813     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
814     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
815     */
816    public static double cos(double radians)
817    {
818        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814 + 1.0;
819        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
820        radians -= floor;
821        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
822        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
823    }
824
825    /**
826     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
827     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
828     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
829     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
830     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
831     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
832     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
833     * is closely related to {@link #sway(float)}, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
834     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
835     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
836     * potentially higher errors, though.
837     * <br>
838     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
839     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
840     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
841     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
842     * and likewise for doubles.
843     * <br>
844     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
845     * by a measurable amount.
846     * <br>
847     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
848     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
849     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
850     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
851     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
852     */
853    public static float sin(float radians)
854    {
855        radians *= 0.6366197723675814f;
856        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
857        radians -= floor;
858        radians *= 2f - radians;
859        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
860    }
861
862    /**
863     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
864     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
865     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
866     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
867     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
868     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
869     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
870     * is closely related to {@link #sway(float)}, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
871     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
872     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
873     * potentially higher errors, though.
874     * <br>
875     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
876     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
877     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
878     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
879     * and likewise for doubles.
880     * <br>
881     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
882     * by a measurable amount.
883     * <br>
884     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
885     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
886     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
887     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
888     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
889     */
890    public static float cos(float radians)
891    {
892        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814f + 1f;
893        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
894        radians -= floor;
895        radians *= 2f - radians;
896        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
897    }
898    /**
899     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
900     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX, you should
901     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sinDeg() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
902     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
903     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes one angle in degrees,
904     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
905     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
906     * is closely related to {@link #sway(float)}, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
907     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
908     * all points between -360 and 360, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
909     * potentially higher errors, though.
910     * <br>
911     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
912     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
913     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
914     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
915     * and likewise for doubles.
916     * <br>
917     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
918     * by a measurable amount.
919     * <br>
920     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
921     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
922     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
923     * @param degrees an angle in degrees as a float, often from 0 to 360, though not required to be.
924     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
925     */
926    public static float sinDegrees(float degrees)
927    {
928        degrees = degrees * 0.011111111111111112f;
929        final int floor = (degrees >= 0.0 ? (int) degrees : (int) degrees - 1) & -2;
930        degrees -= floor;
931        degrees *= 2f - degrees;
932        return degrees * (-0.775f - 0.225f * degrees) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
933    }

935    /**
936     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
937     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX, you should
938     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cosDeg() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
939     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
940     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes one angle in degrees,
941     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
942     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
943     * is closely related to {@link #sway(float)}, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
944     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
945     * all points between -360 and 360, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
946     * potentially higher errors, though.
947     * <br>
948     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
949     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
950     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
951     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
952     * and likewise for doubles.
953     * <br>
954     * Unlike in previous versions of this method, the sign of the input doesn't affect performance here, at least not
955     * by a measurable amount.
956     * <br>
957     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
958     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
959     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
960     * @param degrees an angle in degrees as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
961     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
962     */
963    public static float cosDegrees(float degrees)
964    {
965        degrees = degrees * 0.011111111111111112f + 1f;
966        final int floor = (degrees >= 0.0 ? (int) degrees : (int) degrees - 1) & -2;
967        degrees -= floor;
968        degrees *= 2f - degrees;
969        return degrees * (-0.775f - 0.225f * degrees) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
970    }
971
972    /**
973     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
974     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
975     * to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
976     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
977     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
978     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
979     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
980     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
981     * <br>
982     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin_(float)}, so you should
983     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
984     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
985     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
986     * and likewise for doubles.
987     * <br>
988     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
989     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
990     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
991     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
992     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
993     */
994    public static double sin_(double turns)
995    {
996        turns *= 4.0;
997        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
998        turns -= floor;
999        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
1000        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
1001    }
1002
1003    /**
1004     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
1005     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
1006     * to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
1007     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
1008     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
1009     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
1010     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
1011     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
1012     * <br>
1013     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(float)}, so you should
1014     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
1015     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
1016     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
1017     * and likewise for doubles.
1018     * <br>
1019     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
1020     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
1021     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
1022     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
1023     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
1024     */
1025    public static double cos_(double turns)
1026    {
1027        turns = turns * 4.0 + 1.0;
1028        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
1029        turns -= floor;
1030        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
1031        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
1032    }

1034    /**
1035     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
1036     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
1037     * building block for other measurements; to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to
1038     * 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
1039     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
1040     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
1041     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
1042     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
1043     * method).
1044     * <br>
1045     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin_(double)}, so you should
1046     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
1047     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
1048     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
1049     * and likewise for doubles.
1050     * <br>
1051     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
1052     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
1053     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
1054     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
1055     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
1056     */
1057    public static float sin_(float turns)
1058    {
1059        turns *= 4f;
1060        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
1061        turns -= floor;
1062        turns *= 2f - turns;
1063        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
1064    }
