1066    /**
1067     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
1068     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
1069     * building block for other measurements; to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal
1070     * to 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
1071     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
1072     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
1073     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
1074     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
1075     * method).
1076     * <br>
1077     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(double)}, so you should
1078     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
1079     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
1080     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
1081     * and likewise for doubles.
1082     * <br>
1083     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
1084     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
1085     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
1086     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
1087     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
1088     */
1089    public static float cos_(float turns)
1090    {
1091        turns = turns * 4f + 1f;
1092        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
1093        turns -= floor;
1094        turns *= 2f - turns;
1095        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
1096    }
1097
1098    /**
1099     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than LibGDX's atan2
1100     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
1101     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
1102     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1103     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to LibGDX'
1104     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1105     * Credit to StackExchange user njuffa, who gave
1106     * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/1105038">this useful answer</a>. This method changed from an earlier
1107     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
1108     * {@link #atan2Rough(double, double)} if the speed isn't good enough with this method and lower quality is OK, or
1109     * {@link #atan2_(double, double)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
1110     * that method returns an angle from 0.0 (equal to 0 degrees) to 1.0 (equal to 360 degrees).
1111     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1112     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1113     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double
1114     */
1115    public static double atan2(final double y, final double x)
1116    {
1117        /*
1118a := min (|x|, |y|) / max (|x|, |y|)
1119s := a * a
1120r := ((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a
1121if |y| > |x| then r := 1.57079637 - r
1122if x < 0 then r := 3.14159274 - r
1123if y < 0 then r := -r
1124         */
1125        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
1126        final double ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1127        if(ax < ay)
1128        {
1129            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1130                    r = 1.57079637 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
1131            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? -3.14159274 + r : 3.14159274 - r : (y < 0.0) ? -r : r;
1132        }
1133        else {
1134            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1135                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
1136            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? -3.14159274 + r : 3.14159274 - r : (y < 0.0) ? -r : r;
1137        }
1138    }
1139
1140    /**
1141     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than LibGDX's atan2
1142     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
1143     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
1144     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1145     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to LibGDX'
1146     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1147     * Credit to StackExchange user njuffa, who gave
1148     * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/1105038">this useful answer</a>. This method changed from an earlier
1149     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
1150     * {@link #atan2Rough(float, float)} if the speed isn't good enough with this method and lower quality is OK, or
1151     * {@link #atan2_(float, float)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
1152     * that method returns an angle from 0f (equal to 0 degrees) to 1f (equal to 360 degrees).
1153     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1154     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1155     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float
1156     */
1157    public static float atan2(final float y, final float x)
1158    {
1159        /*
1160a := min (|x|, |y|) / max (|x|, |y|)
1161s := a * a
1162r := ((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a
1163if |y| > |x| then r := 1.57079637 - r
1164if x < 0 then r := 3.14159274 - r
1165if y < 0 then r := -r
1166         */
1167        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
1168        final float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1169        if(ax < ay)
1170        {
1171            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1172                    r = 1.57079637f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
1173            return (x < 0f) ? (y < 0f) ? -3.14159274f + r : 3.14159274f - r : (y < 0f) ? -r : r;
1174        }
1175        else {
1176            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1177                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
1178            return (x < 0f) ? (y < 0f) ? -3.14159274f + r : 3.14159274f - r : (y < 0f) ? -r : r;
1179        }
1180    }
1181
1182    /**
1183     * Less-precise but somewhat faster approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with
1184     * worse average and max error than {@link #atan2(double, double)} but better error all-around than the old
1185     * implementation of atan2() in SquidLib. Should be up to twice as fast as {@link #atan2(double, double)}.
1186     * Should be fine for things at coarse-grid-level precision, like cells in a dungeon map, but less fitting for tasks
1187     * like map projections that operate on finer grids.
1188     * <br>
1189     * Credit to Sreeraman Rajan, Sichun Wang, Robert Inkol, and Alain Joyal in
1190     * <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/3321724_Streamlining_Digital_Signal_Processing_A_Tricks_of_the_Trade_Guidebook_Second_Edition">this DSP article</a>.
1191     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1192     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1193     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double
1194     */
1195    public static double atan2Rough(final double y, final double x)
1196    {
1197        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0.0;
1198        final double ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1199        if(ax < ay)
1200        {
1201            final double a = ax / ay,
1202                    r = 1.57079637 - (a * (0.7853981633974483 + 0.273 * (1.0 - a)));
1203            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? -3.14159274 + r : 3.14159274 - r : (y < 0.0) ? -r : r;
1204        }
1205        else {
1206            final double a = ay / ax,
1207                    r = (a * (0.7853981633974483 + 0.273 * (1.0 - a)));
1208            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? -3.14159274 + r : 3.14159274 - r : (y < 0.0) ? -r : r;
1209        }
1210    }
1211
1212    /**
1213     * Less-precise but somewhat faster approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with
1214     * worse average and max error than {@link #atan2(float, float)} but better error all-around than the old
1215     * implementation of atan2() in SquidLib. Should be up to twice as fast as {@link #atan2(float, float)}.
1216     * Should be fine for things at coarse-grid-level precision, like cells in a dungeon map, but less fitting for tasks
1217     * like map projections that operate on finer grids.
1218     * <br>
1219     * Credit to Sreeraman Rajan, Sichun Wang, Robert Inkol, and Alain Joyal in
1220     * <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/3321724_Streamlining_Digital_Signal_Processing_A_Tricks_of_the_Trade_Guidebook_Second_Edition">this DSP article</a>.
1221     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1222     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1223     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float
1224     */
1225    public static float atan2Rough(final float y, final float x)
1226    {
1227        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
1228        final float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1229        if(ax < ay)
1230        {
1231            final float a = ax / ay,
1232                    r = 1.57079637f - (a * (0.7853981633974483f + 0.273f * (1f - a)));
1233            return (x < 0f) ? (y < 0f) ? -3.14159274f + r : 3.14159274f - r : (y < 0f) ? -r : r;
1234        }
1235        else {
1236            final float a = ay / ax,
1237                    r = (a * (0.7853981633974483f + 0.273f * (1f - a)));
1238            return (x < 0f) ? (y < 0f) ? -3.14159274f + r : 3.14159274f - r : (y < 0f) ? -r : r;
1239        }
1240    }
1241
1242    /**
1243     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as 
1244     * doubles and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 1.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
1245     * equivalent to 360 degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians,
1246     * or by {@code 360f} to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles. Will never return a
1247     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
1248     * Credit to StackExchange user njuffa, who gave
1249     * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/1105038">this useful answer</a>. Note that
1250     * {@link #atan2(double, double)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
1251     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
1252     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1253     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1254     * @return the angle to the given point, as a double from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive
1255     */
1256    public static double atan2_(final double y, final double x)
1257    {
1258        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
1259        final double ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1260        if(ax < ay)
1261        {
1262            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1263                    r = 0.25 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
1264            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? 0.5 + r : 0.5 - r : (y < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
1265        }
1266        else {
1267            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1268                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
1269            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? 0.5 + r : 0.5 - r : (y < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
1270        }
1271    }
1272    /**
1273     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as floats
1274     * and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0f to 1.0f, with one cycle over the range equivalent to 360
1275     * degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians, or by {@code 360f}
1276     * to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats. Will never return a negative number, which
1277     * may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
1278     * Credit to StackExchange user njuffa, who gave
1279     * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/1105038">this useful answer</a>. Note that
1280     * {@link #atan2(float, float)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
1281     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
1282     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1283     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1284     * @return the angle to the given point, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive
1285     */
1286    public static float atan2_(final float y, final float x)
1287    {
1288        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0f;
1289        final float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1290        if(ax < ay)
1291        {
1292            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1293                    r = 0.25f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
1294            return (x < 0.0f) ? (y < 0.0f) ? 0.5f + r : 0.5f - r : (y < 0.0f) ? 1f - r : r;
1295        }
1296        else {
1297            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1298                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
1299            return (x < 0.0f) ? (y < 0.0f) ? 0.5f + r : 0.5f - r : (y < 0.0f) ? 1f - r : r;
1300        }
1301    }

1304    /**
1305     * Less-precise but somewhat faster altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with
1306     * worse average and max error than {@link #atan2(double, double)} but better speed. Takes y and x positions as
1307     * floats and returns an angle from 0.0f to 1.0f, with one cycle over the range equivalent to 360 degrees or 2PI
1308     * radians. Should be up to twice as fast as {@link #atan2_(double, double)}.
1309     * Should be fine for things at coarse-grid-level precision, like cells in a dungeon map, but less fitting for tasks
1310     * like map projections that operate on finer grids.
1311     * <br>
1312     * Credit to Sreeraman Rajan, Sichun Wang, Robert Inkol, and Alain Joyal in
1313     * <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/3321724_Streamlining_Digital_Signal_Processing_A_Tricks_of_the_Trade_Guidebook_Second_Edition">this DSP article</a>.
1314     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1315     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1316     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double
1317     */
1318    public static double atan2Rough_(final double y, final double x)
1319    {
1320        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0.0;
1321        final double ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1322        if(ax < ay)
1323        {
1324            final double a = ax / ay,
1325                    r = 0.25 - (a * (0.7853981633974483 + 0.273 * (1.0 - a))) * 0.15915494309189535;
1326            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? 0.5 + r : 0.5 - r : (y < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
1327        }
1328        else {
1329            final double a = ay / ax,
1330                    r = (a * (0.7853981633974483 + 0.273 * (1.0 - a))) * 0.15915494309189535;
1331            return (x < 0.0) ? (y < 0.0) ? 0.5 + r : 0.5 - r : (y < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
1332        }
1333    }

1377//    /**
1378//     * Arc sine approximation with fairly low error while still being faster than {@link NumberTools#sin(float)}.
1379//     * This formula is number 201 in <a href=">http://www.fastcode.dk/fastcodeproject/articles/index.htm">Dennis
1380//     * Kjaer Christensen's unfinished math work on arc sine approximation</a>. This method is about 40 times faster

1389    /**
1390     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(double, double)}.
1391     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but on some versions of OpenJ9 it is slower
1392     * (while also being less precise than Math's implementation). It's likely that OpenJ9 will be able to undo a
1393     * performance regression, but not likely that Math.asin() will speed up by 30x (Math.sin() has sped up, though).
1394     * @param n an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1395     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
1396     */
1397    public static float asin(final float n)
1398    {
1399        final float ax = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
1400        if(ax < ay)
1401        {
1402            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1403                    r = 1.57079637f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
1404            return (n < 0f) ? -r : r;
1405        }
1406        else {
1407            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1408                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
1409            return (n < 0f) ? -r : r;
1410        }
1411    }

1417//     * to arc cosine. This method is faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}.

1426    /**
1427     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(float, float)}.
1428     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but on some versions of OpenJ9 it is slower
1429     * (while also being less precise than Math's implementation). It's likely that OpenJ9 will be able to undo a
1430     * performance regression, but not likely that Math.asin() will speed up by 30x (Math.sin() has sped up, though).
1431     * @param n an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1432     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
1433     */
1434    public static double asin(final double n)
1435    {
1436        final double ax = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
1437        if(ax < ay)
1438        {
1439            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1440                    r = 1.57079637 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
1441            return (n < 0.0) ? -r : r;
1442        }
1443        else {
1444            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1445                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
1446            return (n < 0.0) ? -r : r;
1447        }
1448    }
1449    /**
1450     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(double, double)}.
1451     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but on some versions of OpenJ9 it is slower
1452     * (while also being less precise than Math's implementation). It's likely that OpenJ9 will be able to undo a
1453     * performance regression, but not likely that Math.acos() will speed up by 30x (Math.sin() has sped up, though).
1454     * @param n an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1455     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
1456     */
1457    public static double acos(final double n)
1458    {
1459        final double ax = Math.abs(n), ay = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n);
1460        if(ax < ay)
1461        {
1462            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1463                    r = 1.57079637 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
1464            return (n < 0.0) ? Math.PI - r : r;
1465        }
1466        else {
1467            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1468                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
1469            return (n < 0.0) ? Math.PI - r : r;
1470        }
1471    }

1486    /**
1487     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(float, float)}.
1488     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but on some versions of OpenJ9 it is slower
1489     * (while also being less precise than Math's implementation). It's likely that OpenJ9 will be able to undo a
1490     * performance regression, but not likely that Math.acos() will speed up by 30x (Math.sin() has sped up, though).
1491     * @param n an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1492     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
1493     */
1494    public static float acos(final float n)
1495    {
1496        final float ax = Math.abs(n), ay = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n);
1497        if(ax < ay)
1498        {
1499            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1500                    r = 1.57079637f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
1501            return (n < 0f) ? 3.14159265358979323846f - r : r;
1502        }
1503        else {
1504            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1505                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
1506            return (n < 0.0) ? 3.14159265358979323846f - r : r;
1507        }
1508    }

1510    /**
1511     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1512     * range from 0.75 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.25 (inclusive).
1513     * <br>
1514     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1515     * @param n a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin() or cos()
1516     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(double)}
1517     */
1518    public static double asin_(final double n)
1519    {
1520        if(n == 0.0) return 0.0;
1521        final double ax = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
1522        if(ax < ay)
1523        {
1524            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1525                    r = 0.25 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
1526            return (n < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
1527        }
1528        else {
1529            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1530                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
1531            return (n < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
1532        }
1533    }
1534    /**
1535     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1536     * range from 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.5 (inclusive).
1537     * <br>
1538     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1539     * @param n a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin() or cos()
1540     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(double)}
1541     */
1542    public static double acos_(final double n)
1543    {
1544        final double ax = Math.abs(n), ay = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n);
1545        if(ax < ay)
1546        {
1547            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1548                    r = 0.25 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
1549            return (n < 0.0) ? 0.5 - r : r;
1550        }
1551        else {
1552            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1553                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
1554            return (n < 0.0) ? 0.5 - r : r;
1555        }
1556    }

1559    /**
1560     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1561     * range from 0.75f (inclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.25f
1562     * (inclusive).
1563     * <br>
1564     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1565     * @param n a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin() or cos()
1566     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(float)}
1567     */
1568    public static float asin_(final float n)
1569    {
1570        if(n == 0.0f) return 0.0f;
1571        final float ax = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
1572        if(ax < ay)
1573        {
1574            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1575                    r = 0.25f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
1576            return (n < 0.0f) ? 1.0f - r : r;
1577        }
1578        else {
1579            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1580                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
1581            return (n < 0.0f) ? 1.0f - r : r;
1582        }
1583    }
1584    /**
1585     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1586     * range from 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.5f (inclusive).
1587     * <br>
1588     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1589     * @param n a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin() or cos()
1590     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(float)}
1591     */
1592    public static float acos_(final float n)
1593    {
1594        final float ax = Math.abs(n), ay = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n);
1595        if(ax < ay)
1596        {
1597            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
1598                    r = 0.25f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
1599            return (n < 0.0f) ? 0.5f - r : r;
1600        }
1601        else {
1602            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
1603                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
1604            return (n < 0.0f) ? 0.5f - r : r;
1605        }
1606    }
1607}
